awd_titl_txt: IUCRC Planning Grant University of Southern California: Center for CO2 Storage Modeling, Analytics, and Risk Reduction Technologies (CO2-Smart)
awd_abstract_narration:
Geologic CO2 storage offers a viable option for reducing CO2 in the atmosphere. Successful implementation of projects in this area hinges on scientific and technological advances in multi-physics flow modeling, subsurface monitoring data analytics, and risk assessment and mitigation strategies. This Industry-University Collaborative Research Center for CO2 Storage Modeling, Monitoring, Analytics, and Risk Reduction Technologies (CO2-SMART) aims to create a synergistic research program to accelerate the development, adaptation, and deployment of novel AI-enriched technologies to enable efficient and safe implementation of the geologic storage of CO2. The prospective members of the Center include the main CO2-producing sectors of the industry, including upstream and downstream oil and gas companies, chemical and petrochemical companies, as well as power plants and utility companies. The Center will train the next generation of engineers and scientists as future leaders for implementing and managing large-scale GCS projects. This will help to address one of the most pressing challenges of our time with broad and significant societal, energy security, and public health impacts. The Center will be guided by an industry advisory board of Center members who will assist it in maintaining its focus on addressing the emerging industry challenges for successful implementation of CO2 storage in the subsurface.
   
The technical focus of the Center will be on integrating recent advances in multi-physics modeling and simulation, subsurface monitoring data acquisition, and modern AI and data science algorithms to develop reliable technologies for safe and sustainable subsurface geologic storage of CO2. The emerging AI-based technologies are bound to replace the traditional labor-intensive modeling workflows with efficient automated platforms, where big data analytics is used not only to enhance data processing, visualization, and management, but also to provide advanced physics-informed predictive analytics, anomaly/fault detection, and decision support capabilities for real-time operation. The Center will focus on several key research and development thrust areas, including (1) modeling and characterization of subsurface fluid, rock, and fracture properties, as well as the parameters pertaining to the underlying multi-physics processes, (2) multiscale and multi-physics modeling and prediction of subsurface flow processes, (3) high-resolution dynamic characterization and imaging using multi-physics monitoring data modalities and advanced deep learning architectures, (4) modern risk assessment and uncertainty quantification technologies pertaining to complex multi-physics systems, and (5) optimization and control of the injected CO2 plume movement under risk and uncertainty. Developing and advancing state-of-the-art technologies in these research areas will directly benefit the industry members and serve the general industrial and scientific communities, as well as the public at large.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The research team members attended a virtual bootcamp during February-April 2024. Under the guidance of NSF representatives, team members engaged over 60 potential IAB members, across energy, environment and technology sectors, through meetings and informational interviews on pain points and unmet challenges in the deployment of large-scale geologic carbon storage (GCS) to form the research vision and the initial research thrust areas of the proposed Center. The planning workshop was organized by USC team members and hosted at the University of Southern California Hotel on September 12-13, 2023. The workshop was the culmination of extensive Industry Advisory Board recruitment efforts that involved dozens of individual interviews and conversations with potential IAB members. Representatives of 15 companies attended the Planning Workshop and participated in extensive discussion on the proposed projects and how the Center can maximize its benefits to prospective members. The event also helped our team gain experience in successfully running future IAB meetings.

With the support of facilitators at Venturewell, the team shared proposal materials with potential future IAB members via Airtable in advance of the Planning Workshop. Prospective IAB members were invited to ‘preview’ and comment on the projects on Airtable. At the Planning Workshop, researchers presented their proposals, and Workshop attendees provided questions, feedback, and comments on each project. On the second day of the planning workshop, a mock voting session was held to simulate the experience of IAB project selections, and projects were debated among future IAB members, culminating in a ranking and mock project selection. After receiving constructive feedback, the team selected the most favored projects for inclusion in the Phase I proposal. The researchers extensively reviewed and revised the projects presented at the planning workshop to better address the concerns of potential future IAB members. In addition, more extensive cross-site collaboration plans were developed for each project. As a results of these efforts, the research team prepared and submitted a Phase-I IUCRC proposal in December 2023.
